title: 109_s2636
content: The "Oil Company Accountability Act" may be cited as the short title. It introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Oil Company Accountability Act" introduces an Energy Tax Rebate where each individual is treated as having made a $500 payment against the tax for the taxable year beginning in 2006. The Secretary will remit this payment to eligible taxpayers within 30 days of enactment, excluding individuals with no adjusted gross income or exceeding $120,000 in the preceding taxable year. The section excludes individuals with no adjusted gross income or exceeding $120,000 in the preceding taxable year, those eligible for a deduction under section 151, estates or trusts, and nonresident alien individuals. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to title 31, United States Code. The Oil Company Accountability Act amends section 1324(b)(2) of title 31, United States Code. A new item is added to the table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Energy Tax Rebate under Sec. 6430 will take effect upon the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there will be a revaluation of LIFO inventories for large integrated oil companies. The Energy Tax Rebate under Sec. 6430 will be implemented upon the Act's enactment, along with a revaluation of LIFO inventories for large integrated oil companies in their last taxable year ending in 2005. Section 4611 adjusts gross income by the layer adjustment amount and decreases cost of goods sold. If the increases exceed cost of goods sold, gross income is increased by the excess. The layer adjustment amount is $18.75 multiplied by the historic LIFO layer. The layer adjustment amount under Sec. 4611 is calculated as $18.75 multiplied by the number of barrels of crude oil represented by the historic LIFO layer. The layer adjustment amount under Sec. 4611 is calculated as $18.75 multiplied by the number of barrels of crude oil represented by the historic LIFO layer. The term "barrel-of-oil equivalent" is defined in section 29(d)(5). Any adjustment required by this section is not considered a change in method of accounting. No addition to tax shall be made under section 6655 for underpayments of estimated tax. No addition to tax shall be made under section 6655 for underpayments of estimated tax related to the taxable year described in subsection (a) if the underpayment was created or increased by this section. An "applicable integrated oil company" is defined as an integrated oil company with average daily worldwide production. An "applicable integrated oil company" is defined as an integrated oil company with average daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels and gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 for its last taxable year ending in 2005. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES FOR LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. Section 901 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by these companies will not be considered a tax. Large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers will not have any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States considered as a tax if the country does not impose a generally applicable income tax or if the amount exceeds a certain limit determined by regulations. The paragraph explains that for dual capacity taxpayers, any amount exceeding the limit set by regulations, paid to a foreign country without a generally applicable income tax, will not be considered as a tax. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to a person subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession of the United States. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to a person subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession of the United States, who receives a specific economic benefit from that country or possession. The term 'generally applicable income tax' is defined as an income tax in this context. The term 'generally applicable income tax' refers to an income tax imposed by a foreign country or possession on income derived from a trade or business within that country or possession. The term 'generally applicable income tax' refers to an income tax imposed by a foreign country or possession on income derived from a trade or business within that country or possession. Exceptions to this tax include those that do not apply to dual capacity taxpayers, citizens, or residents of the foreign country or possession. A 'large integrated oil company' is defined as an integrated oil company for a specific taxable year. The term 'large integrated oil company' is defined as an integrated oil company with gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 and a daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil for a specific taxable year. The effective date for the amendments made by this section is specified. The amendments apply to large integrated oil companies with a daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil, effective for taxable years after the enactment date. Treaty obligations of the United States are upheld.
